I'm in Michigan, and our governor and Democratic-majority state house and Senate are working hard to protect civil rights. There is a difference between the two parties. It's important to be engaged and to vote. End of soapbox. ☺️

...the vote, I was trying to say that there is quite a large distance between the parties in many policy areas (still acknowledging the need for pushing from the left). The student loan forgiveness act was put forth by Biden, challenged by his opponents, destroyed by SCOTUS. It's Biden's bill.

I understood you saying something like this: "Rattner, a democrat, tweeted a shitty opinion about the SCOTUS decision on student loan forgiveness. Why bother voting for Democrats at all if they're going to praise bad decisions?"

Since there's a long history of conflating parties and discouraging

I didn't say that you said that. I said that I will continue to vote for Democrats (and critique them from the left) even when they disappoint me, as they invariably do, to protect the civil rights the Christian Dominionists are trying to destroy.

Critique from the left is essential. 
Obama's not president and his "we can be bipartisan and work together gambit" largely failed due to sabotage from those who opposed him. And he had plenty of unforced errors, too.

I'm interested to see Biden's response to SCOTUS shooting down loan forgiveness.

While I'm frequently frustrated with the Democrats, I'm unwilling to let trans kids and other vulnerable populations die in order to support accelerationism.

Also, Trump destroyed the Supreme Court, and Rattner, a Wall St financier, is not representative of Democrats in general.

Rattner's an aptly-named and problematic neoliberal, but the last time I checked, we don't vote for members of a presidential task force. And Republicans are aggressively pursuing fascism.

(I paid off my student loan after 30(!!) years and strongly support student loan forgiveness for everyone.)
